ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This course was a live zoom class throughout.
We only met synchronously on Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I got an overview of the theoretical basis and developments in anthropology and the concept of modernity, with a focus on how it plays out in ethnographies of East Asian culture.

I received a good platform to understand social theories and ways to apply them in my research. The course which was lecture based also had interactive sessions. This helped in cross referencing theories with the contemporary world. A very exciting class!
I learned a lot about social theory and anthropological applications, it was super interesting and I appreciate the breath of theoretical topics that the course covers.

Stronger basis on social theory. Skill of article review. Thinking much about power involution, re-appropriation of state discourse/ideology. complication of colonial dynamics. introduction to research proposal writing norms.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course introduced me to many important thinkers and Professor Siu is amazing at explaining the connections between the readings she chose for that week. However, students did not get many chances to participate and the class seemed more like a small lecture than a seminar at times.
This class has been an eye opener in terms of understanding the intersection between culture and representation. Its strength is that it covers very important issues, and some excellent authors.

Strengths: If you like theory, you will love basically every reading that is assigned. Very few, if any, of the readings felt like a chore. I really enjoyed interacting with the ideas presented in the class.
Weaknesses: The course is a seminar, but feels like a lecture. Since it's so long (and virtual) it is a little difficult to keep focused on the class lecture/discussion.

Professor Siu is an expert in her field and there is so much to learn from her. I was grateful each week to listen to her lectures and document her insights. She did a great job of circling back to certain concepts she mentioned in various lectures, and I think the readings she foregrounded every week [as opposed to other smaller or, perhaps, less complex readings] were very generative. All the readings were great with such diversity in subject matter. I loved how the professor emphasized meeting with her at least once throughout the semester. That one on one time was very illuminating and underscored just how much we had to learn from Professor Siu. 

I believe this course could improve if the students has more ability to exchange ideas. I'm sure this is a function of Zoom. But I left class sometimes wondering what my more quiet classmates were thinking.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class was great the way it was!
I think the Professor was readily accessible, and eager to meet with students over Zoom.

There were paper extensions that were very caring. I believe we could have executed presentations on Zoom as I had for other courses. Instead of these presentations we wrote 2 midterm papers. In hindsight, we were able to manage these two papers and this was very much thanks to the extensions.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this to any anthropology major wanting to get a theoretical grounding in the subject or anyone who wants to learn more about concepts of modernity today.
Yes! I would recommend this to anyone who wants to understand social theories and their intersection with culture!

Yes! It was really enjoyable, it definitely worked out my brain and critical thinking skills, and I exercised a lot of theoretical knowledge in the course. Very fun and stimulating, I applied a lot of course concepts from this class in my other classes.
I would recommend this course to another student looking to get a firm a basis in social theory.
